objectives.title: General Security Concepts
objectives.description: Compare and contrast various types of security controls and fundamental security concepts

objectives.title: Threats, Vulnerabilities, and Mitigations
objectives.description: Explain common threat actors and threat intelligence sources, common attack types, and application attacks

objectives.title: Security Architecture
objectives.description: Compare and contrast security implications of different architecture models

objectives.title: Security Operations
objectives.description: Apply common security techniques to computing resources and explain the importance of security concepts

objectives.title: Security Program Management and Oversight
objectives.description: Summarize governance and compliance concepts and explain risk management processes

questions.questionText: Which type of security control is a firewall considered to be?
questions.explanation: A firewall is a technical (also called logical) security control because it uses technology to enforce security policies and protect systems from network-based threats.

questions.questionText: What is the principle of least privilege?
options: Users should have the minimum access rights needed to perform their job
All users should have the same level of access
Privileges should be rotated among users
questions.explanation: The principle of least privilege states that users should be given the minimum levels of access – or permissions – needed to perform their job functions. This reduces the potential damage from accidents or malicious actions.

questions.questionText: Which type of malware encrypts files and demands payment for the decryption key?
questions.explanation: Ransomware is a type of malware that encrypts a victim's files or entire system and demands payment (ransom) in exchange for the decryption key to restore access.

questions.questionText: What type of attack involves an attacker intercepting communication between two parties?
questions.explanation: A man-in-the-middle (MITM) attack occurs when an attacker intercepts communication between two parties, potentially allowing them to eavesdrop on or modify the communication.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is a characteristic of a zero-day vulnerability?
options: It has been patched by the vendor
It is unknown to the vendor
It requires physical access to exploit
questions.explanation: A zero-day vulnerability is a software vulnerability that is unknown to the vendor and therefore has no available patch. Attackers can exploit these vulnerabilities before they are discovered and fixed.

questions.questionText: What is the primary purpose of network segmentation?
questions.explanation: Network segmentation primarily serves to reduce the attack surface by dividing a network into smaller segments, limiting an attacker's ability to move laterally through the network if one segment is compromised.

questions.questionText: Which cloud service model provides the most control to the customer?
questions.explanation: Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) provides the most control to the customer, as they manage the operating systems, applications, and data while the cloud provider manages the underlying infrastructure.

questions.questionText: What is the purpose of a honeypot?
questions.explanation: A honeypot is a security mechanism designed to attract and detect attackers by appearing to be a legitimate target. It helps identify attack patterns and diverts attackers from real systems.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is the BEST method for securely disposing of data on a solid-state drive (SSD)?
questions.explanation: Physical destruction is the most secure method for disposing of data on SSDs because wear-leveling and garbage collection make traditional overwriting unreliable, and degaussing is ineffective on flash memory.

questions.questionText: What type of log would contain information about user authentication attempts?
questions.explanation: Security logs (also called audit logs) contain information about security events, including user authentication attempts, access control changes, and other security-related activities.

questions.questionText: Which authentication factor is based on something you are?
questions.explanation: Biometric authentication factors like fingerprints are based on 'something you are' - physical characteristics unique to an individual. This is one of the three main authentication factor categories.

questions.questionText: What is the primary purpose of a vulnerability scan?
questions.explanation: A vulnerability scan is designed to identify potential security weaknesses in systems, networks, and applications. It helps organizations discover vulnerabilities before attackers can exploit them.

questions.questionText: Which framework is commonly used for managing and reducing cybersecurity risk?
questions.explanation: The NIST Cybersecurity Framework provides a policy framework of computer security guidance for organizations to assess and improve their ability to prevent, detect, and respond to cyber attacks.

questions.questionText: What does GDPR stand for?
questions.explanation: GDPR stands for General Data Protection Regulation, a comprehensive data protection law that applies to organizations handling EU citizens' personal data, regardless of the organization's location.

questions.questionText: Which type of risk response involves accepting the potential cost of a risk?
questions.explanation: Risk acceptance involves acknowledging a risk and accepting the potential cost or impact if it occurs, typically when the cost of mitigation exceeds the potential loss or the risk is within acceptable limits.

questions.questionText: What is the purpose of separation of duties?
questions.explanation: Separation of duties is a security principle that divides critical tasks among multiple people to prevent fraud and errors. No single person should have complete control over a critical process.

questions.questionText: Which attack exploits the trust relationship between a user and a website?
questions.explanation: Cross-site request forgery (CSRF) exploits the trust that a website has in a user's browser by tricking the browser into sending unauthorized commands to a website where the user is authenticated.

questions.questionText: What is defense in depth?
questions.explanation: Defense in depth is a security strategy that implements multiple layers of security controls throughout an IT system. If one layer fails, other layers continue to provide protection.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is an example of a preventive control?
questions.explanation: An access control list (ACL) is a preventive control because it prevents unauthorized access before it occurs. Cameras and IDS are detective controls, while audit logs are typically used for detective or corrective purposes.

questions.questionText: What type of encryption uses the same key for both encryption and decryption?
questions.explanation: Symmetric encryption uses the same key for both encrypting and decrypting data. This is faster than asymmetric encryption but requires secure key distribution.

questions.questionText: Which protocol provides secure remote access to network devices?
questions.explanation: SSH (Secure Shell) provides encrypted remote access to network devices, replacing insecure protocols like Telnet that transmit data, including passwords, in clear text.

questions.questionText: What is the primary purpose of a Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) system?
options: To aggregate and analyze security logs
questions.explanation: A SIEM system aggregates and analyzes security logs from multiple sources in real-time, providing centralized monitoring, threat detection, and incident response capabilities.

questions.questionText: Which of the following best describes a supply chain attack?
options: Compromising a trusted third-party to reach the actual target
questions.explanation: A supply chain attack involves compromising a trusted third-party vendor or supplier to gain access to the actual target organization, exploiting the trust relationship between organizations.

questions.questionText: What is the purpose of a chain of custody?
options: To maintain the integrity of evidence
To share evidence with law enforcement
questions.explanation: Chain of custody documents the handling of evidence from collection through presentation in court, maintaining its integrity and ensuring it hasn't been tampered with or altered.

questions.questionText: Which type of backup includes all data regardless of when it was last backed up?
questions.explanation: A full backup includes all selected data regardless of when it was last backed up. While it requires the most storage space and time, it provides the simplest restoration process.
